item.title: A new favorite
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
Coloring is a new favorite for Joanna.  My original plan was to just try and use it to keep her entertained (and still) during church.

But when she found her notebook this morning and kept signing "please" I just couldn't resist. The high chair is helping het have a surface and keep the color contained to one place.

A small desk or table may be in our near future :)

item.title: Ready to ride
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded: Joanna has quite a grip and she likes to use it. We attached a couple of toys to the sun shade on her car seat and she used them to pull it down. After a reset, I got a good shot of her getting ready to go for a car ride, but it looks more like she's getting ready to jump out of a plane!

item.title: She thinks she's ready.
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded: Joanna's thinking "please daddy, I really want some Pepsi" and she can almost get the cup to her mouth. I'm pretty sure Pepsi shouldn't be the first thing she drinks from a cup.
item.excerpt:encoded: Joanna's thinking "please daddy, I really want some Pepsi" and she can almost get the cup to her mouth. I'm pretty sure Pepsi shouldn't be the first thing she drinks from a cup.

item.title: Good to have friends!
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded:
After church tonight we spent some time trying to figure out how to work it out for the guys of 3 families to go see Captain America while the 5 kids, one exchange student and 3 women got dinner, complicated by one of the women having a PTA meeting to go to.

In the end the guys left to go see the movie, the PTA atendee, 2 kids, exchange student, and I went to her house while the other lady took her 3 kids with her to go get McDonalds for 8 of us. I stayed at the house while 1 left for meeting and hung out with three waiting for dinner, to be brought by the other adult, and 3 more kids. It was a fun night!

Since the weather was finally less than 100 we took the kids to the park after dinner. Being pregnant, I got to drive my friend's car to take the 3 youngest and exchange student just around the corner while my friend walked the 2 oldest kids.

A good time was had by all!

It's so good to have friends that live nearby!

-Jessica
item.excerpt:encoded: After church tonight we spent some time trying to figure out how to work it out for the guys of 3 families to go see Captain America while the 5 kids, one exchange student and 3 women got dinner, complicated by one of the women having a PTA meetin...

item.title: Movin' & Groovin'
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
I keep meaning to write this stuff down, but I don't take the time enough to do it, so here's the recap of the past couple of months, in no particular order:

  • saw the baby, she'll be here in October!
  • felt the baby move
  • she moves A LOT. Sonogram tech said she "has personality".
  • learned "personality" is code for squirmy, so we get another one to finish what she couldn't measure the first time.
  • went to Vegas for a week-long getaway (thanks Uncle Father Tom!)
  • climbed inside the Hoover Dam — what a view!
  • enjoyed the first fruits (okay, vegetables) of our garden with our friends the Bailey's
  • that first zucchini was HUGE
  • went to physical therapy for back/neck problems. Better, but still a problem.

There's more, and each of those could probably warrant their own post, but that's all for now I guess. I think I'll call that caught up and try to write as events happen.

Morgan

item.title: Joanna at Chelino's
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
Joanna got her first taste of guacamole in her first restaurant high chair!

She definitely has her mama's tastes (and, sometimes, her daddy's crazy hair).
item.excerpt:encoded: Joanna got her first taste of guacamole in her first restaurant high chair! She definitely has her mama's tastes (and, sometimes, her daddy's crazy hair).

item.title: Sweet moments
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded:
A trip to the pediatrician resulted in Joanna being diagnosed with jaundice and being prescribed phototherapy. This meant she had to stay under lights all day except when being fed or having her diaper changed.

It was tough having to put her in a box of lights basically all the time and having to wrap her in a belt of light when she was eating.

We were so glad to find out from the home health nurse today that her level has dropped and we could stop the light treatment!

We took her out, dresses her, and cuddled with her. It was great!

- Jessica
item.excerpt:encoded: A trip to the pediatrician resulted in Joanna being diagnosed with jaundice and being prescribed phototherapy. This meant she had to stay under lights all day except when being fed or having her diaper changed. It was tough having to put her in a ...

item.title: I love Morgan's encouragement!
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
This photo is my foot, getting a much needed pedicure.

One of the hard parts of Oklahoma has been how much more expensive this is here than it was in San Diego. Morgan seems to always notice specials for me and encourages me to go on and get one. Most of the time I just pass.

But, tonight after another errand he totally encouraged me to come on in a new place and get one. He offered to run some other errands and get coffee while I'm here in the massaging chair getting my toes done. And, so far so good.

It'll be nice to walk out with nicely trimmed and painted toes!

Jessica

item.title: Our first house - day 1
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded: WeWe  signed the contract on our first house in mid-March, then closed June 7th.  That sure felt like a long time, we waited so long because the previous owner's son was in school and they wanted to let him finish before moving.  We are in the process of painting the whole inside, so this video is a "before" one, to give an idea what it looked like before we started working in there.

item.title: Nursing + Netflix = warning from AT&T
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
Jessica got a nicely-worded text and email from AT&T this afternoon. It turns out that the woman who didn't want a smart phone is now in the top 5% of all subscribers for data usage. Woohoo!

According to the email, AT&T considers "extraordinarily large amounts of data" to be about 12x the amount that the average smartphone user would use. We're 16 days into the billing cycle and Jessica has already used over 2GB worth of data. In comparison, I have used a whopping 768MB in that same time, and I'm what could be considered a "power user."

So how did this happen? For starters, Jessica doesn't use WiFi on her phone. She turned it on once before but it kept prompting her to connect to all the networks throughout the neighborhood every time she drove through. Her solution: since we pay for unlimited data, just use the 3G connection.

And that worked, until now (warning: technical rant follows...)

AT&T has decided to start throttling connections to devices that are high users of data. Their solution is technically okay (they do it by month, then give you full speed at the start of the next month), but they don't really define to what speed they limit the connection, nor at what threshold of data usage that kicks in. They are quick to point out that we still have unlimited data, just that it'll be slower than it is now (which isn't really blazing, to be honest.)

/end rant

And how was she able to rack up so much data? Here's the rundown:

  • Joanna eats about 8 times a day for 30-45 minutes each time.
  • Netflix streams TV shows to the iPhone.
  • McCleod's Daughters is a fun show.
  • Episodes are about 43 minutes long.
  • It takes about 0.215GB per episode to stream (0.3GB/hr).

Conservatively, we'll say she gets to watch 2 episodes a day while breastfeeding.

2 episodes × 0.215GB = 0.43GB/day

That's about 4.5 days of feeding and watching (plus email, Facebook, Words With Friends, etc.) to be in the 5%. At that rate, I can guesstimate (and so can AT&T) that Jessica would use close to 13GB of data in a month (feel free to check my math) at full speed. Woohoo again!

Oh yeah, we've set up the phone for WiFi again, but not to prompt to connect to available networks. She'll still chew up the Interwebs, but it'll be partly on Cox's network now.
item.excerpt:encoded: Jessica got a nicely-worded text and email from AT&T this afternoon. It turns out that the woman who didn't want a smart phone is now in the top 5% of all subscribers for data usage. Woohoo! According to the email, AT&T considers "extraordinarily ...

item.title: Lunchtime fun
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
Jessica had the day off for Fall Break, so she and Joanna trekked out to Long John Silver's for lunch -- where I happily joined them.

Joanna got to taste greasy chicken and greasy fish, and seemed to enjoy both. We definitely won't make this a habit for her, as we're trying to break ourselves of bad eating habits.

But for today, it made J a happy girl!

item.title: We have a flower!
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded: It was so cool to see that this flower opened up overnight. What a fun, beautiful surprise!

item.title: Life is good
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
It was a bit of a rough day, after a series of long days getting the
house ready. Tonight was WoW at Memorial Road, but I just wasn't
feeling up to worship. I had a talk with a friend about work (he and I
share similar positions in different companies) and wasn't cheered up
too much.

Then, things got better real fast. Six - count 'em: 6 - guys showed up
at our apartment to help move our heaviest furniture to our house.
After that, they all agreed to a second trip! Even though we're all
members at he same church, some of them had never met, so it was a
chance to bring them together as well.

To top off the night, I looked in my closet and found two bundles of
freshly laundered and pressed dress shirts!

Yep, life is good.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Sorry I'm not the encouraging one in this story! :-( Glad it worked out well, though.

<html><body bgcolor="#FFFFFF"><div>Sorry, it sounds worse than it was. You taught me to be content where I am and that I&#39;m not alone in my struggle. Thanks!<br><br>Sent from my iPhone</div><div><br></div></body></html>

item.title: Naming the blog
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
For a while now we’ve thought about sharing a blog…with family living in other states it seemed like it could be a good way to keep in touch with them as well as a fun project for the two of us.

Morgan started one for us years ago (he can't hardly resist new technology) but neither of us really posted much.  So, it seemed worth giving a new shot and posterous seemed like a nice, easy to share service.  Once we decided to do it we had to answer a question - what do we call it?  

"Home for Now" became the winner!  There were a variety of factors, one big one could be that we bought our first house and were in the process of cleaning, repairing, and painting it to get it ready for us to live in.  But, even more than that the idea of "home" was an intriguing one.

When I was a student at Pepperdine and we went somewhere for a service project people would often ask "where's your home" or, "where are you from".  That was a tricky question for me - I grew up in Indianapolis, and basically considered that home, but at that time I was also living on campus and considering that home.  It was not a short answer during those years. 

When my Grandma Rita was still living and I lived in California and Oklahoma every time we spoke she asked me when I'd be coming home - since she lived in Indy and I grew up there, she called that "home" when we talked.  Each summer when Morgan and I have done Let's Start Talking projects we've called the place we stayed home - whether it was a church building, empty apartment, family's house, or a hotel room.  At the end of a long work day one of us would often say "let's go home" and we meant the place we were staying in that country - not the home in the States where the rest of our stuff was.  There's an old hymn with lyrics this world is not my home, I'm just a passing through" that expresses the idea that our ultimate home is in heaven.

So, for lots of reasons, Edmond is "home for now" and that seemed like an appropriate name for our blog.  We hope you enjoy keeping up with us through this.
item.excerpt:encoded: For a while now we’ve thought about sharing a blog…with family living in other states it seemed like it could be a good way to keep in touch with them as well as a fun project for the two of us.Morgan started one for us years ago (he can't hardly ...

item.title: One for the birds
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
One of the things Jessica wanted for Christmas was a bird feeder for our big back yard. We have a huge pecan tree that is home to a family of squirrels, some cats float through from time to time, but we don't get many birds. We thought a bird feeder might change things a bit.

Well, I had no idea how many bird feeder options there were, nor what kind of birds we wanted to attract. We went shopping and decided to start with a simple wooden feeder for small birds, and a general purpose bird seed that listed the same birds as the feeder did. The only question was where to hang the feeder.

We thought that the best place to hang the feeder was outside the window in our kitchen dining area. We have a good one that would let us watch the birds from our living room and breakfast nook. The only problem was that we're a bit impatient and nature didn't come quick enough for us. After talking to our friend Sarah B's parents about all their birds, we decided to move our feeder to the tree in an effort to entice the birds in their environment. Bad idea.

Thievin' squirrels...

That's right, the same squirrel family that cleaned our our entire pecan crop decided they like bird seed as well. They cleaned it out not once, but twice. I'm a slow learner - I filled it up thinking the birds ate the seed. It wasn't until after I filled it again that I saw the pile of seed on the ground with choice sunflower seeds missing. After that, we decided to move it back to our original place.

Snowmageddon hit Oklahoma just then, so we left the feeder out, with snow piling up. As it thawed, we started to see birds coming around, but none at the feeder. Jessica saw pidgeons at the pile under the tree, and the pile that spilled on the porch was cleaned up.

Finally, we started to see birds at the feeder! Those little guys are flighty, though (forgive the pun), so it's been hard to get a close look. We've seen little ones, medium ones, dark ones and red-headed ones. They come in ones and twos, sometimes on the same side, sometimes on opposite. They chase each other away, and fly away when I try to get close enough to take a picture. They're fun.

Today, though, I was able to get a picture. I've had my camera on the table so I can reach it quickly but even reaching to grab it scares them away. I figured out that I could stand off to the side a bit where the birds couldn't immediately see me and snap a couple of quick ones before they flew away and it worked. Here's a couple of shots, one of the beautiful feeder against the sky, and another with a hungry bird deciding on a snack. Here's hoping they keep coming back!
item.excerpt:encoded: One of the things Jessica wanted for Christmas was a bird feeder for our big back yard. We have a huge pecan tree that is home to a family of squirrels, some cats float through from time to time, but we don't get many birds. We thought a bird feed...

item.title: Gardening!
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded:
This year has been our first attempt at a garden.  It's been pretty interesting.  
We planted quite a few things on April 18th and most of them seem to be going pretty well.  

Pictures from the beginning and from today are available at http://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.560420811724.2060260.168301576&l...

We're looking forward to enjoying some vegetables this summer/fall!

Jessica

item.title: Standing
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded:
We took part in OC's Trick or Treat Night tonight. For our first 5 years here I was responsible for two dorms of mostly college sophomores who participated in handing out candy to the children that came. It was always a crazy night - fun, but crazy. We usually had over 300 costumed kids come through.

Tonight we got to experience receiving the candy rather than handing it out.

Joanna was decked out in a ladybug costume we got from someone a while back. She grabbed her treat bucket (I got a happy meal at McDonald's for my lunch today so we'd have a bucket) and hung on to it the whole time as fun college students dropped in pieces of candy.

Just after taking the picture with our sweet friends from church she stood on her own for the longest things she has yet. Yes, she had a baby doll in one hand and a treat bucket in the other, but she just stood there as we looked on in amazement.

What a fun night seeing lots of friends from our time he on Edmond. It's fun being home here in Edmond and at OC.

item.title: First flight
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded:
Thursday, December 1st was Joanna's first flight. We flew to Indy to be with my family after my cousin Zac passed away. We left OKC at 1:25, changed planes at DFW and arrived in Indy at 7:10. Joanna did great!

Before leaving OKC she was screaming, but after som tummy drops she calmed down and hardly made a peep the rest of the way.

Morgan did a great job helping her get through take-off and landing. He encouraged her to suck on her pacifier and massaged behind her ears. She didn't seem affected by the pressure changes at all.

I even got to change her in the plane bathroom, the fold down table worked just fine. Being short I can actually stand in there without ducking so that was helpful.

She sure attracts attention in the airport! Even if she's not making a sound people see her and comment how cute she is or how much they like her red hair. It's pretty cool.

Hopefully the return flights Sunday will go just as well.

-Jessica
item.excerpt:encoded: Thursday, December 1st was Joanna's first flight. We flew to Indy to be with my family after my cousin Zac passed away. We left OKC at 1:25, changed planes at DFW and arrived in Indy at 7:10. Joanna did great! Before leaving OKC she was screaming,...

item.title: New Life!
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
We have a flower at the corner that was tall and beautiful when it bloomed. Then it turned hard and gray. You can see the talk gray stalk in the photo, that used to be green with a pretty flower on top.

But, now there is new growth - the green is just visible at the bottom of the picture.

I don't know yet if it will grow up to become a flower or nit, but I do see the hope of new life in it. I love that about plants, so often they look finished, but a little attention and water and they come back!

I think people can be the same, there are times that we look finished, yet a little love goes a long way and we spring back!

Jessica Estes

item.title: Give a day, get a Disney day
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
When we found out we were coming to CA for the CR Summit and that we'd have a free day at the end we started scheming about what we'd do with that day. There are lots of options, but Disney surfaced to the top, especially once we figured out we could go for free!

Our group spent a night at the Regional Food Bank of Oklahoma helping after the ice storms last winter. It was a fun team bonding experience and made it so we could all come to Disneyland today for free!

It's been a fun day. We took a break in the late afternoon for dinner and came back to ride a few more rides.

Morgan and I have had a great time re-visiting our engagement spot.

I'm glad for the volunteer day, for our friends, and for our day here today!

Jessica

item.title: Settling Catan
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
I love that we live near our friends Josh & Sarah! It makes it easy to play "Settlers of Catan" with them. Tonight her parents have joined us and it's been really fun!

Jessica

item.title: Repurposing the grill
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
The Navy has a history of scuttling old ships to make artificial reefs for ocean life and divers to enjoy. I have a feeling that I've unexpectedly done the gas grill equivalent in my back yard.

I was hanging out with Joanna in our living room yesterday and gazing out at our back yard when I saw two birds hanging out around the wood pile on the porch. A couple of minutes' observation showed me that one of them was acting as a lookout while the other went to work on the grill, dipping in and out of the drip can underneath. After a minute of feeding from the can, it surprised me by jumping up inside the grill itself, through the small-ish hole in the bottom!

There's not a nest inside the grill yet, but I suspect it's just a matter of time. Maybe it's time to retire this grill to a corner of the yard and open it up as a feeding/nesting ground for little birds. It's already teeming with wildlife, and I need a good excuse for a new grill, right?
item.excerpt:encoded: The Navy has a history of scuttling old ships to make artificial reefs for ocean life and divers to enjoy. I have a feeling that I've unexpectedly done the gas grill equivalent in my back yard. I was hanging out with Joanna in our living room yest...

- Jessica

item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes

She tried to order lamb fries, but mamma wasn't having any of that nonsense, as you can see in this picture.

item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
We planted the plants April 28th and today one of the pepper plants has a start of a pepper!

Hopefully the rest of the plants will follow the example of this one and we'll have some good food this summer!

Jessica Estes

item.title: Playing!
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded:
Joanna has quite a few toys already, some received at baby showers, and some at Christmas. She's just now getting to be able to hold on to things other than our fingers, so we're bringing out some of them for her. This turtle is part of a set received at Christmas. She seemed to enjoy hanging onto it tonight, and slobbering all over it.

Thanks for the gift, Nana and Papa!

-Jessica

item.title: Serving at Tealridge
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
Recently our Sunday morning class asked for guys to help lead a service at Tealridge for this month. Since we're in town this holiday weekend Morgan signed up to help.

Here he is before it began -we got there a bit early just to be sure we weren't late.

I'm so thankful that I am married to a man who is so willing to help out when the church asks!

It was a nice service, with some of our friends also helping. The residents at Tealridge were very appreciative. Being there reminded me of my Grandma Rita going so often to visit people living in homes. She sure was a good example of showing love to others.

Jessica Estes
www.threadsokc.org

item.title: Groundhog Day One
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded:
We're teaching Joanna's class this quarter. That means 12 weeks of singing the same program to little ones - up to 10 little 8 & 9 month olds. While I already appreciated the men and women that teach the kiddos, I have a whole new respect for those who do it over and over again after just this one day. Today was our first day. It was so neat to watch our three little ones checking it all out, I'm looking forward to seeing them change and grow over the next few months. It was surprisingly exhausting even though all 3 kids did a great job. Yes, J is a bit removed from the other two. When I put her in the chair right next to the boy she promptly reached over and "caressed" his cheek, then his eye, so she got moved. Morgan did a great job carrying the singing while I searched for and helped distribute the props. Here's hoping the next eleven classes pass very quickly :)

On a more serious note, I really appreciate the education ministry at MRCC, the leaders do a great job of providing good materials, starting right from the youngest class on up. Organizationally, they ask that parents teach a quarter per child that attends class. I think it's great that they expect us all to be involved. I'm looking forward to meeting more parents of Joanna's classmates, as these kids will be growing up together and it'll be neat to start forming those relationships now. - Jessica
item.excerpt:encoded: We're teaching Joanna's class this quarter. That means 12 weeks of singing the same program to little ones - up to 10 little 8 & 9 month olds. While I already appreciated the men and women that teach the kiddos, I have a whole new respect for thos...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: HI, just trying this to see if we can comment back to you! lu J
@Jan - yep, we just moderate comments so they don't show up right away.

item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes

Joanna's starting to roll, and that means she's on her way to being mobile!
I'm so not ready for that, yet.

item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded: We have no idea what Joanna is trying to say, but she sure says it a lot. I love watching her "wind up" before she squeaks, it's like she has to prepare for her next big sound.
item.excerpt:encoded: We have no idea what Joanna is trying to say, but she sure says it a lot. I love watching her "wind up" before she squeaks, it's like she has to prepare for her next big sound.

item.title: Scarves for Threads
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
These are the 22 scarves that Threads of Compassion OKC gave to the YWCA last night. This brings our total to 130 scarves donated so far!

It's been pretty neat to see this project grow this year. Our contact at rhe Y said that it has been really cool to see what an impact these are making when they give them to people.

I'm thankful for all the help that I've had with this!

item.title: LST -how I got started
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
I think it could be fun to share a few of those lessons that I’ve learned through my 14 Let’s Start Talking mission projects.

 

When I first heard about LST in 1993 as a freshman at Pepperdine I thought “I’d love to do that, but no way, I have to go home and work and see my family, I couldn’t spend half the summer overseas.” It sounded like a neat idea, but just not right for me at the time.  Then, a couple years later one of the guys in my small group Bible study asked our group to pray for their project, they needed 1 more person to join them as the church there had requested 4 and at that time they only had 3. After a couple of weeks of this, I thought “maybe I can be that 4th person.” We talked about it and worked it out!  We did a special weekend of training together to get me caught up on what I’d missed and we kept on going with the training to get ready to go.  I wasn’t sure how the whole fundraising thing would work, especially since I started late. One part of that first experience really sticks out; a family at church asked how my fundraising was going and when they heard I was about half way there and coming up to a deadline they stepped in and helped finish it up. What a great blessing to me and reminder that God really does provide when we ask!

 

There are so many different things I’ve learned, I think instead of cramming it all in here I’ll try & do a quick summary about each project in a separate post. Maybe I’ll wait till we get our pictures out of storage so I can scan and include a picture with them, we’ll see.

 

For today, here’s a list of all the projects, just so I can keep them straight…

 

1996 Montevideo, Uruguay (team of 4 from Pepperdine University)

1998 Lomonosov, Russia (team of 4 from Pepperdine University)

1999 San Miguelito, Panama City, Panama (team of 6 from Crowley’s Ridge College + me)

2000 Cuernavaca, Mexico (4 person team 2 from Oklahoma Christian University and 2 from Louisiana)

2000 Singapore Friends Camp in December

2001 Kampala, Uganda (me and Dyann)

2002 Eindhoven, Holland (4 person team; 2 from CVCC in San Diego and 2 from Pepperdine)

2003 Cologne, Germany (4 person team from CVCC in San Diego)

2004 Vitoria, Brazil (5 person team from CVCC in San Diego)

2005 Lausanne, Switzerland (me and Morgan)

2006 Ghent, Belgium (me and Kristy)

2007 Xian, China (me and Morgan)

2008 Rio de Janeiro, Brazil (me and Morgan)

2009 Panama City, Panama (me and Morgan)

 

Jessica
item.excerpt:encoded: I think it could be fun to share a few of those lessons that I’ve learned through my 14 Let’s Start Talking mission projects. When I first heard about LST in 1993 as a freshman at Pepperdine I thought “I’d love to do that, but no way, I have to go...

item.title: Like Mother Like Daughter?
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded:
A little known fact: bell peppers are one of my favorite foods. My Grandma Rosie knew about my love for them and would quietly make sure that family gatherings included a veggie tray with them, even though not many other family members care for them. One of my aunts has continued that tradition and made sure that the times I've been expected at gatherings in recent years there are some peppers on the table.

A good friend here in Edmond knows about my fondness for them and had some available at our potluck on Monday night. They were yummy! And, to my delight, there were some left over. She let me know that I was welcome to take home the extras at the end of the night; we left early due to J's bedtime so I didn't remember to take them with me, but my friend delivered them to my house last night. What a blessing! 

So, we decided to see what Joanna thought about them and let her "gnaw" on one of each as I held her and the pepper. It seemed she liked them too, as you can see in her smiley face above. We think she preferred the red, but liked the green as well. Once we finished, she did her best to grab the bag of them and try to figure out how to get some out.

We have 3 pepper plants in our garden, I'm sure hoping they produce an abundant crop this year that we can enjoy and share with friends (and with Joanna!).
item.excerpt:encoded: A little known fact: bell peppers are one of my favorite foods. My Grandma Rosie knew about my love for them and would quietly make sure that family gatherings included a veggie tray with them, even though not many other family members care for th...

item.title: Hard at work...
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
Morgan got to put our new shovel to work today.

After a morning of yummy breakfast and some TV watching he took care of our driveway as well as one of our neighbors. I sure love his willingness to serve!

Jessica

item.title: The walking begins
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
While visiting Grandpa Joe, Joanna is getting the opportunity to play with Cousin Austin's toys. This one is a convertible car/walker that she immediately took to.

It's only a couple of steps, but Joanna is definitely on the move in bigger ways than maybe we're ready for!
item.excerpt:encoded: While visiting Grandpa Joe, Joanna is getting the opportunity to play with Cousin Austin's toys. This one is a convertible car/walker that she immediately took to. It's only a couple of steps, but Joanna is definitely on the move in bigger ways th...

item.title: Thankful for thankfulness
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
Jessica is blessed with the gift of encouragement, and one way that
she expresses it is through giving cards to folks. I'm not talking “go
to the grocery store and grab a card” cards, but thoughtfully written
cards for someone she's thinking of. In fact, we have an entire
dresser dedicated to cards and writing paraphernalia that we've
gathered through the years just for this purpose.

Most recently, Jessica sat down to write thank you cards to the over
20 friends who helped us prepare our new house and get moved in. It
was great to take a few minutes to think about how each one if them
helped us out recently, and how great it is to be part of a church
family that is so willing to help others.

Here's a shot of Jessica with 18 cards that she had just finished…and
there's still more to come!

item.title: See's Candies
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded:
One of my friends just came back from several days in southern California. Before he left I asked if he could bring me some chocolates. He agreed. I gave him a list and some cash and he brought me back some See's. What a treat!

- Jessica
item.excerpt:encoded: One of my friends just came back from several days in southern California. Before he left I asked if he could bring me some chocolates. He agreed. I gave him a list and some cash and he brought me back some See's. What a treat!- Jessica

item.title: Dear Pfizer:
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
Pfizer, this is my plea to you concerning your infant's Advil. Please take inspiration (read: steal heavily) from your Tylenol-ish counterparts and change your bottle to one that doesn't make me have to hose of the sticky mess each time I have to cajole my daughter into taking medicine.

Sincerely,

A dad whose already frazzled with a sick baby and who doesn't want to deal with your sticky mess.

Pictured: at left is the glass bottle containing a sticky solution of Advil along with the syringe that I must stick all the way into the bottle to get a dose. At right is the Walgreens brand of acetaminophen, with the nice, clean syringe that makes it much easier to dose. All three brands of acetaminophen we've used have the same system just waiting to be copied by the Advil packaging team.
item.excerpt:encoded: Pfizer, this is my plea to you concerning your infant's Advil. Please take inspiration (read: steal heavily) from your Tylenol-ish counterparts and change your bottle to one that doesn't make me have to hose of the sticky mess each time I have to ...

item.title: A WHOLE six weeks?!
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
When I started my current position with the Oklahoma Bar Association back in February 2009, one of the benefits mentioned was the geat parental leave policy. Not intending to have kids, I didn't think much of it. I may have even had a snarky reply that it was one benefit I'd never use.

Now, 2.5 years later, I am really thankful for it. I get six weeks of paid parental leave to be at home with Jessica and Joanna. Six weeks to help care for Jessica (who has just undergone major surgery) and Joanna (who is freaking out in this new world).

Folks seem absolutely amazed that my work gives me this much time off. Some are even more surprised that I'm taking it! I say that this is probably the best time for me to take off. Personally, it's important to me and my family; professionally, it's reassuring to know that the ship still sails without me and I can trust the folks who are backing me up. Winning all around!

The work is challenging. The benefits: outstanding.
item.excerpt:encoded: When I started my current position with the Oklahoma Bar Association back in February 2009, one of the benefits mentioned was the geat parental leave policy. Not intending to have kids, I didn't think much of it. I may have even had a snarky reply...

item.title: "Well, do you want to get full?"
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded:
At lunch today Morgan and I decided to share the "fisherman's friend" lunch and add a 2nd salad. When we told the waitress that we wanted to share she said "I can do that, but, well do you want to get full, I'm not sure that will be enough".

We assured her it would be fine. Being pregnant I eat often but not a lot at once. Also we each got a trip through the packed salad bar.

As she walked away I told Morgsn that it would likely be a photo- worthy plate. And, I was right - it was a ton of food! We both ended up totally full and didn't even stuff our salad bowls as much as we could have.

Just another big meal out to eat here in America!

- Jessica

item.title: 2011 "Blizzard"
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
It may be time for us to get double-paned windows.

We have ice on the inside of our bedroom window today! I even chiseled out "hi".

Actually, in spite of icy windows and snow all around we are nice & warm inside, enjoying a snow day at home together

Jessica

item.title: Crocheting Together
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
Starting Threads of Compassion OKC in January this year was a great move. I'm so glad Morgan encouraged me to do it!

Yesterday was a work day for Threads and we had a great time in the afternoon working together. We learned new techniques from each other and enjoyed seeing the variety of styles.

I look forward to next month's work day!

Jessica Estes
www.threadsokc.org

item.title: I love my life!
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
It’s true, I love my life!  While there are plenty of things that aren’t fun, or are even hard to deal with, overall I’ve got it great!  The most recent experience that makes me say yes! has to do with arranging a place to stay when Morgan and I go to California for a couple of vacation days before a seminar next month. 

 

One of my college friends sent me a facebook message awhile back to let me know that she had some yarn she wanted to donate to Threads of Compassion OKC.  In writing back and forth about that we decided it would be fun to try to see each other when we’re out there next month.  She offered for us to stay at her house, but already has company, so it wouldn’t really work very well for us to crash there too. 

 

Yesterday she let me know that she has a friend who has moved out of their apartment and doesn’t have to turn in the keys until the end of the month so if it’s not already spoken for, we can stay  in their empty apartment while we’re in town.  How cool! 

 

I think the last time I saw this friend was in April of 2003 when we ran into each other at the Pepperdine Bible Lectures.  We don’t even email very often, but she’s putting her creative juices to work to find a way not only to see us when we’re in Southern CA, but also to help us save a night’s hotel cost.  It’s just great,  I love to see the amazing variety of ways that God always provides!

 

~Jessica
item.excerpt:encoded: It’s true, I love my life! While there are plenty of things that aren’t fun, or are even hard to deal with, overall I’ve got it great! The most recent experience that makes me say yes! has to do with arranging a place to stay when Morgan and I go ...

item.title: So much to say
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded:
It sure seems that Joanna has something to say a lot of the time. Of course so far it's just babbling, but it's cute and since our family is all spread out here's another possibly boring to most video that the grandparents will likely enjoy.

- Jessica
item.excerpt:encoded: It sure seems that Joanna has something to say a lot of the time. Of course so far it's just babbling, but it's cute and since our family is all spread out here's another possibly boring to most video that the grandparents will likely enjoy.- Jessica

item.title: Easter traditions
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
We have certain things we do around holidays that have become family traditions: unhealthy but sooooo yummy snacks for Easter, dad's chili at Thanksgiving, fudge during the winter, almonds and oranges in the stockings at Christmas, that sort of thing.

We got our Easter package from my folks yesterday, and once again they did not disappoint! The Peeps are one of my favorites, Jessica likes the Snickers eggs (now there's a bunny!), and we both enjoy the creme eggs. Good stuff.

Joanna even got in on the action and tried to grab it all out of my hands when I opened the package. Even if I'm tempted to let her lick the inside of the Cadbury eggs, she's just not ready. Instead, she got some bibs. With the amount of drool flowing from her, those are much needed! She also got two cool squeezy/grabby things - and elephant and a giraffe. Since she has a tendency to grab everything in her reach and slam it into her face as she's aiming for her mouth, those are bound to be in heavy rotation.

I like family traditions.
item.excerpt:encoded: We have certain things we do around holidays that have become family traditions: unhealthy but sooooo yummy snacks for Easter, dad's chili at Thanksgiving, fudge during the winter, almonds and oranges in the stockings at Christmas, that sort of th...

item.title: Lighting for the laundry room!
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
Our laundry room is between the garage and kitchen. It's not much wider than a washing machine, but the light switch is on the wall just inside the garage. This means that when I go to do laundry I can't hit the light switch with my arms full of clothes.

So, Morgan fixed it for me! (he's really good at that).

Here is the original switch (that was on the "wrong" side of the room when I'm trying to do laundry.

And, here is the new motion detector switch! It doesn't matter that it's on the far side of the room because it turns on automatically when I walk toward it. So cool!

Not only is it great when I'm doing laundry, but I'm looking forward to it lighting my way once I start parking in the garage.

It's amazing what a good difference a $20 part and a handy husband can make!

Jessica

item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded: Today was pleasantly warm, so we took Joanna to the neighborhood park before dinner. We had a good time, just another benefit of living where we do.

item.title: A freebie for the grandparents
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
We got new phones with pretty nice cameras, so we've been shooting lots of pics and videos of our favorite subject. Here's one that we're pretty sure will entertain the grandparents!
By the way, J has a thing for eating toes (and not just her own).

item.title: A Sunday Tradition
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
Sometimes it's fun to have a tradition, and Morgan and I have developed one over the last couple of years, Red Lobster for lunch on Sunday!

I think it started when we were trying to eat healthier. I found out I liked tilapia by trying it on the school cafeteria, I figured if I liked it there it was worth trying at a retaraunt. The tradition continued with some great gift cards from family!

At our healthiest we were sharing a grilled tilapia and adding a salad.

Here it is, the tilapia prepared on the wood fired grill. It's great to get it at least once a month, sometimes twice!

item.title: Babble on
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
Joanna's babbling up a storm tonight! She especially wanted to chat us up during our bedtime Bible reading time, which helps explain the audio-only video (lights off at bed time.)

Enjoy!

item.title: Tomatoes!
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded: There are 2 little tomatoes on my plant! I had begun to think we weren't going to get any tomatoes because of some yellow leaves and flowers that didn't become tomatoes. But, this morning there are 2 on this plant and one on our yellow plant. I look forward to eating them!
item.excerpt:encoded: There are 2 little tomatoes on my plant! I had begun to think we weren't going to get any tomatoes because of some yellow leaves and flowers that didn't become tomatoes. But, this morning there are 2 on this plant and one on our yellow plant. I lo...

item.title: Your lunch is in the bed of the truck
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
Earlier this week I had an early breakfast with a friend at Colby's Grill. (Side note: that place is GREAT for breakfast.). I had to get up and leave the house earlier than usual, so I didn't have time to make a lunch, and Jessica wasn't up to make it for me like she usually does.

I know, I'm spoiled.

As my friend and I were leaving from breakfast, I got a text from Jessica: "Your lunch is in the bed of the truck."

I read it and laughed, then went into a moment of confusion and panic. What did she mean? I didn't pack a lunch. But maybe I did and forgot. Did she make one and put it in there before I left, so I've been driving around with my lunch box just flopping around the truck?

Crazy, the things that pop in my mind at times like this.

No, the more exciting truth is that Jessica got up after I left, made me a lunch, drove to Colby's Grill, put my lunch in my truck, then went to work where she texted me that it was there.

Way cool.

A good breakfast, an even better lunch.
item.excerpt:encoded: Earlier this week I had an early breakfast with a friend at Colby's Grill. (Side note: that place is GREAT for breakfast.). I had to get up and leave the house earlier than usual, so I didn't have time to make a lunch, and Jessica wasn't up to mak...

item.title: So glad
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded:
I am so glad my dad came to visit!  When he heard me lamenting how crazy-busy things are right now he said he'd check his schedule and see about coming to visit.

It worked out! His recent retirement made it so that he had the time available. How cool that he used it to come help us.

12 hours one way in his truck and a few hundred dollars of gas equal priceless times together. I'm not sure if he or Joanna is having the better time.

What a blessing, thank you Dad for coming to visit!

item.title: A new ride
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded: Living closer to work and having an active toddler to keep up with inspired Morgan to get a bike. We found a great one today, with some help from the local bike shop. He rode it home from the store, already off to a great start!
item.excerpt:encoded: Living closer to work and having an active toddler to keep up with inspired Morgan to get a bike. We found a great one today, with some help from the local bike shop. He rode it home from the store, already off to a great start!

item.title: Green Beans
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded: We (well, I along with approval from Morgan) decided to have a vegetable garden this year. It's been quite a story getting it started, but I'll save that for another day. This picture is some green beans that I started inside from seeds a friend gave me. I plan to move the plants out to the garden once it is warm enough. I planted them the evening of Thursday 3/31. This picture was taken this morning, so it's just a few hours shy of 2 weeks since planting the seeds. It's looking like we may have some fresh green beans to enjoy later this summer!
item.excerpt:encoded: We (well, I along with approval from Morgan) decided to have a vegetable garden this year. It's been quite a story getting it started, but I'll save that for another day. This picture is some green beans that I started inside from seeds a friend g...

item.title: Hi Daddy!
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
Usually when I get home from work or pick her up from the sitter's, Joanna grunts and speed crawls to me with a big smile on her face, but today she was already in her high chair having some dinner.

What greeting did she have for me tonight? A loud "Hi Daddy!" as I entered the kitchen! Jessica and I both heard it loud and clear and confirmed it with each other. It was a fun surprise to hear.
Considering her first clear word was "no!", repeated over and over in line at Homeland, this was a nice second.

item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes

I believe that the lady who sent it learned about Threads of Compassion OKC by the news interview that happened months ago. It's so cool how technology makes it possible for people from all over the place to participate in this project!

item.title: Joanna's first four months - a photobook
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
We used a coupon we got from Shutterfly recently to print 100 free photos. Of course, 95 of those were of Joanna :)

After that, we got another special deal for a free 20-page photo book, so we spent a little while this afternoon picking out some special photos and telling Joanna a story of her first four months.

We thought we'd share it with you here.

Click here to view this photo book larger

Visit Shutterfly.com to create your own personalized photobook.

item.title: Yum...
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded:
Once she found her feet, it didn't take long for them to go into her mouth like everything else these days.

Every diaper change is an opportunity for her to get another chance to lick/suck on her toes.
item.excerpt:encoded: Once she found her feet, it didn't take long for them to go into her mouth like everything else these days.Every diaper change is an opportunity for her to get another chance to lick/suck on her toes.

item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded: Check out that proud smile! She's wanting to stand on her own. Walking must be right around the corner.
item.excerpt:encoded: Check out that proud smile! She's wanting to stand on her own. Walking must be right around the corner.

item.title: Thankful for fire places!
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
We were excited that the house has a fire place, as that was one of the things on our "wish list" when we were house shopping.

A weekend of being home sick combined with a high if 68 turned today into a good afternoon for a fire.

- Jessica
item.excerpt:encoded: We were excited that the house has a fire place, as that was one of the things on our "wish list" when we were house shopping. A weekend of being home sick combined with a high if 68 turned today into a good afternoon for a fire.- Jessica

item.title: Play it again, Jan
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
My dad told me recently that he and my mom will just sit and watch videos of Joanna over and over (which explains the high visit count!). He even told her to watch one recently with the warning "you won't be able to just watch it once."

So with that, here's another video that probably will only appeal to grandparents, or those who want to scare dogs with high-pitched squeals. Enjoy!

Morgan
item.excerpt:encoded: My dad told me recently that he and my mom will just sit and watch videos of Joanna over and over (which explains the high visit count!). He even told her to watch one recently with the warning "you won't be able to just watch it once."So with tha...

item.title: A New Faucet
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
Morgan has made lots of nice improvements in the 9 months we’ve been in our house. We haven’t document all of them, but one that I did take before and after pictures of is the sink in our guest bathroom. While we’re not crazy about the green color in the countertop, it still works so that’s not a big problem. However, the original faucet was so close to the back wall of the sink that it was difficult for me (with my pretty small hands) to get a good hand-washing in there. So, for other adults it was just a pain. Morgan looked at it and said he could switch out the faucet for a new one that would extend further into the sink and be way better to use. He was right! After a quick trip to Home Depot we had a new faucet and he installed it. It’s way better than the old one.

Jessica
item.excerpt:encoded: Morgan has made lots of nice improvements in the 9 months we’ve been in our house. We haven’t document all of them, but one that I did take before and after pictures of is the sink in our guest bathroom. While we’re not crazy about the green color...

item.title: Reading with Friends!
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
A recent Saturday our friends invited us to join them at Barnes & Noble. Their daughter's school was having a fundraiser where the school got a percentage of the day's sales from customers who mentioned the school. We couldn't pass up a good excuse to browse for books, so we headed out there Saturday morning. Morgan is pictured with some of our sweet friends - various teachers from the school came and read children's stories. He joined in to listen with our friends.

This particular family has been a great blessing to us - it's one of the great things about Oklahoma! -Jessica
item.excerpt:encoded: A recent Saturday our friends invited us to join them at Barnes & Noble. Their daughter's school was having a fundraiser where the school got a percentage of the day's sales from customers who mentioned the school. We couldn't pass up a good excus...

item.title: Joanna's first moments
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes

item.title: Seven years and lovin' it
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
Seven years ago today, I watched this beautiful woman walk towards me, surrounded by family and friends, and agreed to be my wife. We celebrated not just the start of our lives together, but also the birthdays of two dear women that we love.

Seven years later, I am still thrilled to see Jessica walking towards me. Then it was in a church; today it was in a restaurant in Missouri with "throwed rolls" flying around. Either place, it is still exciting for me.

I'm glad to say that not only do I love my wife, I really like her, and am looking forward to more years and more friends to celebrate them with.
item.excerpt:encoded: Seven years ago today, I watched this beautiful woman walk towards me, surrounded by family and friends, and agreed to be my wife. We celebrated not just the start of our lives together, but also the birthdays of two dear women that we love. Seven...

item.title: Dancing Queen
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded: I don't know where she gets those dance moves, but they're definitely better than my own.
item.excerpt:encoded: I don't know where she gets those dance moves, but they're definitely better than my own.

item.title: We did it!
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
We got up this morning and walked! For my birthday back in April I asked Morgan to get me a Nike + sensor so that I could use it with my iphone to keep track of workouts. It's been a great motivational tool. It got even better when we got one for Morgan too and he started walking with me.

For several weeks we've been walking together 3 times a week. But the last couple of weeks that has slowed down some with so much of our energy going to getting the house ready. It was good to get back out there today and check out the walking trail right by our house!
item.excerpt:encoded: We got up this morning and walked! For my birthday back in April I asked Morgan to get me a Nike + sensor so that I could use it with my iphone to keep track of workouts. It's been a great motivational tool. It got even better when we got one for ...

item.title: Already interested in the news?
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded: Someone left Grandpa Joe's paper where Joanna could reach it. She had a great time checking it all out.
item.excerpt:encoded: Someone left Grandpa Joe's paper where Joanna could reach it. She had a great time checking it all out.

item.title: It's shot day!
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
Today's follow-up visit with Dr. C brought good news: Joanna's ear infections are gone! That was good news, but that also meant that she got to finally have her 6-month shots. I've added the before, during, and after pics.

Shots are a bit troublesome for all of us, but it shook Jessica up pretty good and Joanna didn't like it very much, either. I was brave and got to hold Joanna's hands while the nurse STABBED MY BABY RIGHT THROUGH HER THIGHS WITH HUMONGOUS NEEDLES AS SHE CRIED AND SHE SCREAMED RIGHT IN MY EARS WHILE SHE WRITHED IN ANGONY OH PLEASE MAKE IT STOP!!!!...
Okay, maybe it affected me a bit, too.

P.S. We actually like Dr. Crittendon and his staff. Ashley does a good job with J. Dr. C wimps out and makes her be the "bad guy" when it comes to shots.
item.excerpt:encoded: Today's follow-up visit with Dr. C brought good news: Joanna's ear infections are gone! That was good news, but that also meant that she got to finally have her 6-month shots. I've added the before, during, and after pics. Shots are a bit troubles...

item.title: Peppers!
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded:
This was quite a year to start a garden. Record heat, drought, pregnancy, a bulging disc and compressed nerve, and water rationing all presented some challenges for us. Then, once the temperature finally dropped below 100 vegetables started growing. Things were looking good then the weather turned again. There was a night or two were it dropped below freezing. After that we picked what was left and got the peppers pictured below. There were lots more little ones that are rotting on the plants. I tried a green and yellow one tonight. They were quite tasty! Here's hoping for better weather next year.

We also have quite a few green tomatoes in a bag that I'm hoping ripen up yet. Jessica
item.excerpt:encoded: This was quite a year to start a garden. Record heat, drought, pregnancy, a bulging disc and compressed nerve, and water rationing all presented some challenges for us. Then, once the temperature finally dropped below 100 vegetables started growin...

item.title: The Presidential Suite
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded:
Our friend offered us a hotel in Anaheim. It ended up being the presidential suite at the Worldmark Hotel, a suite that sleeps 8 and overlooks Disneyland. It was a night of luxury for us.

It was really cool to be able to watch the Disney fireworks from our balcony!
item.excerpt:encoded: Our friend offered us a hotel in Anaheim. It ended up being the presidential suite at the Worldmark Hotel, a suite that sleeps 8 and overlooks Disneyland. It was a night of luxury for us. It was really cool to be able to watch the Disney fireworks...

item.title: A Baby Blanket
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
This one was fun to make! It’s for a friend and co-worker who loves Oklahoma Christian University, so I made it as close to the school colors as I could. It turned out great and their daughter looks real sweet in it. I love being able to make meaningful gifts for friends. It’s also cool that I can pray for the baby & my friends, the soon-to-be parents as I do the stitches. Crocheting has sure been fun for me!

 

Jessica

item.title: "A Christmas Carol"
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
One of our favorite things about our life here in OK is our church family, specifically our Q Group.

We had a great time tonight seeing our 12 year old friend play the role of Scrooge in " A Christmas Carol" at the Children's Theatre tonight.
item.excerpt:encoded: One of our favorite things about our life here in OK is our church family, specifically our Q Group. We had a great time tonight seeing our 12 year old friend play the role of Scrooge in " A Christmas Carol" at the Children's Theatre tonight.

item.title: Getting ready?
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded:
We got to church a bit early since Morgan is helping run the sound board tonight. So we stopped by the kid's play room. J went right for the plane and started playing with controls. She seemed to love sitting in it.

We're headed to Indy later this week, so maybe she's just getting comfortable with the idea of flying. :)

item.title: Cheerio! Pip pip and whatnot!
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded:
In celebration of the Olympics in London, we decided to give Joanna some British-themed rings to chomp on.

Okay, that was a bit of a stretch. Really, we just gave her Cheerios for the first time. Once we made sure they weren't going to be a problem, I did what we usually do with firsts: shot video!

Since she was enjoying it so much, this one's a bit lengthy. Hope you enjoy it.

item.title: Round 1: Sandman
item.dc:creator: Morgan Estes
item.content:encoded: It was well fought, but this round goes to the Sand Man. To her credit, Joanna signed "more" one last time as she fell asleep.
item.excerpt:encoded: It was well fought, but this round goes to the Sand Man. To her credit, Joanna signed "more" one last time as she fell asleep.

item.title: Still fascinated
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded: I know I already posted about her fascination with her toes, but tonight she was so happy slurping on her foot I just had to take a quick video. Hope you enjoy it.
item.excerpt:encoded: I know I already posted about her fascination with her toes, but tonight she was so happy slurping on her foot I just had to take a quick video. Hope you enjoy it.

item.title: A new toy
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded:
We received a cool 3 stage exersaucer as a gift for Joanna. I've been looking forward to moving on to stage 2, the one where she can sit in the middle and play with it. The instructions say that stage begins at 4 months, and we're there now!

Saturday Morgan spent just over an hour putting it all together for us. It ends up that Joanna's height of 23 3/4 inches is just tall enough to use it. She seemed to enjoy her first time in. I'm looking forward to watching her get more and more interested in it as she gets bigger. The legs adjust to 2 more heights, so she should be able to use it for awhile, even as she gets taller.
item.excerpt:encoded: We received a cool 3 stage exersaucer as a gift for Joanna. I've been looking forward to moving on to stage 2, the one where she can sit in the middle and play with it. The instructions say that stage begins at 4 months, and we're there now! Satur...

item.title: Enjoying Chelino's
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded: This is her 2nd taste if Mexican food. We started with guacamole and have moved on to tortillas. She seems to be a fan.
item.excerpt:encoded: This is her 2nd taste if Mexican food. We started with guacamole and have moved on to tortillas. She seems to be a fan.

item.title: Morning fun
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded: Joanna's new morning ritual is climbing in and out of her bouncy seat. She seems so proud once she's in, and so excited once she's out. Here's a peek at her enjoyment.
item.excerpt:encoded: Joanna's new morning ritual is climbing in and out of her bouncy seat. She seems so proud once she's in, and so excited once she's out. Here's a peek at her enjoyment.

item.title: Thankful!
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
We procrastinated on buying a shovel until a few hours before the storm hit. When Morgan got to Home Depot they were out.

So, now that the snow has stopped and we want to clear the drive in case we have to go to work tomorrow we have a bit of a problem.

We have a neighbor who goes to church with us. The only time we've called them prior to today was when we brought home a dresser we needed help unloading. The husband came right over and helped.

So, today when we needed a shovel we made our 2nd call to this family. He once again graciously agreed to help, even leaving a friend's house around the corner to bring us the shovel.

A few minutes later I heard scraping outside - he got here and just started right in clearing the driveway!

Morgan quickly joined him.

About an hour later we had a nice, snow-free driveway.

What a blessing to live so near our church family!

Jessica
item.excerpt:encoded: We procrastinated on buying a shovel until a few hours before the storm hit. When Morgan got to Home Depot they were out. So, now that the snow has stopped and we want to clear the drive in case we have to go to work tomorrow we have a bit of a pr...

item.title: It's fun to be at OC.
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded:
One of the great things about being home at OC is the opportunity to enjoy things happening on campus.

I recently was able to enjoy a flute recital given by one our students, my friend Thomas. He did a great job!

I recorded most of his performance, I hope you enjoy it.    

- Jessica
item.excerpt:encoded: One of the great things about being home at OC is the opportunity to enjoy things happening on campus. I recently was able to enjoy a flute recital given by one our students, my friend Thomas. He did a great job! I recorded most of his performance...

item.title: Nice!
item.dc:creator: HomeForNow
item.content:encoded:
Someone left us dinner on our porch this week! It's so cool that they were thinking of us. I've been amazed at how difficult it has been just to get a decent meal together with a newborn in the house. Though we don't know who dropped this by the house, it truly was a reminder that God provides in an amazing variety of ways and we've got it good here in Edmond. Thank you to whoever brought this by, it truly was appreciated.

- Jessica
item.excerpt:encoded: Someone left us dinner on our porch this week! It's so cool that they were thinking of us. I've been amazed at how difficult it has been just to get a decent meal together with a newborn in the house. Though we don't know who dropped this by the h...

item.title: Not surprising...
item.dc:creator: Jessica Estes
item.content:encoded:
So, I often say that Morgan can fix anything. Tonight he proved my faith in his fix-it ability to be founded in reality yet again

Here he is after fixing a DVD saga:

The DVD player that was connected to our TV hasn't been working right, it skips. This is kind of a big deal since we don't have cable and I'm working my way through the Gilmore Girls series on DVD.

Tonight he heard the skipping and pulled out another player. It's one that we got free awhile back. Once it was connected we remembered why we haven't used it before - no remote came with it. A remote is essential to be able to watch various episodes on the disc.

Using his phone Morgan was able to find the needed codes to program a remote we already had to work with this machine. It worked!

Once again he fixed it! And, now my DVD watching can be back on track.

Jessica
